messageBody:
Hi,

I've had some problems writing tests for methods that return void too.
I most cases it's impossible ( for me anyway ) to change method sigs of
production code, particulaly if the method is exposed thought a
published interface. Not all of you will agree with my solution, but I
wrote some inner classes that morror that methods I'm testing, and uses
these inner classes to validate return values. Also where necessary,
these classes are stripped out when the product is built.

Regards,

~Brendan.

From: jays81 [mailto:jays81@...]

hi,

thanks for that,

i a still slightly confused though!
This is the set up

EventMgtBean contains method dispatch event e.g

public void dispatchEvent(Event event){
handleEvent(event);
}

should i be adding extra methods to my bean to check if my event has
reached the dispatchEvent method and test it in my test class or
should i create a mock object

thanks





--- In junit@y..., Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
> jays81 wrote:
>
> > hi,
> >
> > I am new to this junit testing. I am trying to test void methods.
> > What is the best way of doing this.
> >
> > e.g i am testing a method:
> >
> > void dispatchEvent(Event event)
> >
> > which inside calls handleEvent(event) , in a class called Handle
> > (this is also a void method)
> >
>
> Can you construct the object defining dispatchEvent() with a mock
> representation of a Handle. The MockHandle would effectively just
eat the
> event, and define a wasHandled() method indicating whether the
event was
> received.
>
> public void testEventReceived() {
>
> MockHandle handle = new MockHandle();
> Foo f = new Foo(handle);
>
> f.dispatchEvent(event);
>
> assertTrue(handle.wasHandled());
> }
>
> Notice that by using composition - Foo is composed of a Handle -
the design
> is more testable _and_ flexible. Foo could use different
implementations of
> Handles without requiring modification. Whenever I find something
difficult
> to test, it's an opportunity for a design improvement.
>
> Mike
